posts.name: Capital City BBQ
posts.note: Capital City BBQ is homey eatery preparing smoked meats with signature sauces and Vietnamese classics like pho and banh mi. Capital City BBQ, serves old southern BBQ and Vietnamese cuisine in one restaurant and is located inside of a cellular store. From their website, 'All our food is homemade, and our specialties include Texas-style brisket, North Carolina pulled pork, Kansas City baby back ribs, rib tips, baked mac ‘n’ cheese, and cornbread, as well as our spectacular Vietnamese Pho and Banh Mi dishes. We also have amazing vegan options.' You need to order the beef brisket banh mi.

posts.name: The Cosmos
posts.note: The Cosmos is a funky parlor offering wood-fired pizzas amid space-themed murals, plus arcade games, and a patio. From their website, 'Mind-erasingly good pizza pies hyperthermatically-scorched in a wood-fired oven from the galactic beyond. Tremble, Earthlings!' Food Network said 'For otherworldly pizza with the freshest mozzarella you can get head to Cosmos. Owner Sam Short was inspired by the pizza parlor he visited with his father as a kid. He infused the casual, fun atmosphere with some seriously delicious pies. Try any of their creative offerings or opt for the “Trust Us” and let them bring out a surprise offering that will wow you. They recommend the Trust Us, The Spaceball (meatball sub)'

posts.name: Hunter House Hamburger
posts.note: From their website, ‘Hunter House Hamburgers was born in 1952, featuring sliders, little hamburgers with juicy, sweet onions smashed into the meat and the buns steamed hot. Our butcher, our baker, and our pickle maker are proudly based in Detroit. Our food is always fresh, and our ingredients come from local, family-run businesses, just like ours. Our small, white porcelain pill-box diner is a mainstay on Woodward Avenue, the first paved road in America. It is the oldest operating restaurant and one of the oldest businesses in Birmingham, Michigan. The name Hunter House dates back to when the road was a bypass named Hunter Boulevard, named after John W. Hunter, who helped found Birmingham in 1819. Hunter Blvd. eventually became part of Woodward Ave., as it stretched out from Detroit.’ From the Detroit Eater website, ‘Nestled up against Woodward Avenue and surrounded by relatively new construction, Hunter House Hamburgers’ bright-white hamburger stand is a holdout from a different era. This blue-collar spot specializes in small, greasy-griddled sliders served on steamed buns with pickles and caramelized onions. Dine inside, sit on the patio, or grab a sack full to go.’

posts.name: Kings Bakery
posts.note: Kings Bakery specializes in Mediterranean gourmet flatbreads and sandwiches. They are known for our phenomenal shawarmas and Manou-wiches(cheese bread sandwiches). From the Detroit Eater website, 'The bakery is known as the “home of the manouwich,” a Middle Eastern cheese pie made into a rolled sandwich that was recently featured in an episode of Ugly Delicious on Netflix.'
posts.rcmmnd: David Chang's Netflix show Ugly Delicious

posts.name: Mudgie's Deli and Wine Shop
posts.note: The quaint deli offers table service for house-smoked meat sandwiches, homemade soups, and craft beer. From the Detroit Eater website, ‘Mudgie’s offers an unbeatable variety sandwiches, including the Brooklyn, served warm and made with house-smoked beef brisket, applewood smoked bacon, beer pub cheese, and caramelized maple onions on a brioche roll. Order a beer or a bottle of wine to wash everything down. The shop takes online orders for pickup at the walk-up window and also offers dine-in service. No longer are good sandwiches solely within the purview of wheat eaters. For only $1.25 extra, almost all of the sandwiches found at Mudgie’s can be made on gluten-free bread. Pair one with a bag of original Better  Made potato chips and a Blake’s Hard Cider for a filling, completely GF  meal.’

posts.name: Schvitz Health Club
posts.note: From the Schvitz Health Club website, 'Open to members and guests since 1930, The Schvitz is Detroit’s original urban health club and the only historic bathhouse left in the city. A storied landmark and cultural institution for nearly 100 years, this old-world oasis still offers the very best in ancient heat therapies and holistic healing. Great food and camaraderie will complete your restorative stay. Come unwind, back in time.' From the Netflix show starring David Chang, they serve steaks and other sides.
posts.rcmmnd: David Chang's Netflix show Ugly Delicious

posts.name: Scotty Simpson's Fish and Chips
posts.note: Scotty Simpson’s Fish and Chips is a no-frills spot known for fish and chips, offering American eats such as burgers and fried chicken. From their website, ‘Scotty Simpson’s Fish and Chips has been a Detroit landmark since 1950 when James (Scotty) Simpson opened the doors and started serving fish and chips. Little has changed since then. There have been only three owners since Scotty, (Uncle) Sean Gilmore, and the current owner Harry Barber. Harry has worked at Scotty’s, as the  regulars call it, since 1966.’ From the Detroit Eater website, ‘Scotty Simpson’s has faithfully met Detroiters’ fish and chips needs since  1950. Though the Brightmoor restaurant offers options such as fried smelt and frog legs, the house specialty is Nova Scotian cod and chips fried in a secret batter recipe with fries, a roll, and tartar sauce. Don’t miss the pies, made fresh every Friday.’ Titus retweeted ‘Best fish and chips in the United States. Not surprising because fish and  chips are very popular across the river in Ontario.’

posts.name: Union Woodshop
posts.note: Union Woodshop serves slow-smoked BBQ, wood-fired pizza, and craft beers draw crowds to this hip rustic space. You need to order the Porker, which has a house-ground pork patty, house-made Michigan maple bacon and house-made hotlinks or any of their other BBQ: brisket, chicken, and pork. From their website, ‘It begins and ends in the backlot, with a green hickory smoker that’s on a constant low-temp tear with an assortment of meats. It’s a ritual that starts with a careful rub and ends only when we think it’s time to pull the meat from the bath of smoke we surround it with. Pork butt. Brisket. Spare ribs. Back ribs. Whole birds and chicken wings alike. And bacon. Lots of bacon. Slow-cooked bacon ready to be cut in from thick slabs into magical planks. Thank you, pig, for all you do for us. It is a menu that’s rustic in its delivery and refined in its care. And it’s crafted with hickory on the smoke side and apple and cherry wood on the pizza side. These aren’t conveyor belt byproducts these bear little resemblance to the frozen disks of surplus cheese that have come to pass for pizza today. No, Pizza Coco pies are fired in an 800-degree inferno until the cheese caramelizes, and the ingredients bake into something incredible. No two pies are the same. It’s the kind of oven, the kind of crafted pie, that can take two or three of your favorite toppings and deliver them a thousand different ways.’

posts.name: Warda Patisserie
posts.note: From the Detroit News website about Warda Patisserie, 'Warda Bouguettaya talks about using Michigan produce for her baked creations with such passion you can almost taste the fresh, seasonal bounty. A self-described “complete nerd” when it comes to pastries, Bouguettaya has been cooking and baking in Detroit for a while, and in November her business Warda Patisserie joined forces with established art space and music venue Trinosophes just outside Eastern Market on Gratiot. Warda Patisserie! A small, modern patisserie inspired by the seasons and our previous life and travels in Algeria, France, and Asia. Located in the heart of Midtown Detroit! We are open for dine-in, as well as outdoor patio seating. Our beverages menu includes espresso drinks, organic teas, and a rotation of housemade seasonal drinks.'
